did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Sol Biderman Collection 1958-2003

corpname.part: Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

descriptivenote.p: Collection materials in Portuguese, Spanish, Italian and English.

did.abstract: Brazilian chapbooks, xilogravuras woodblock illustrations and woodblocks, sound recordings and additional research material on the subject of Brazilian literatura de cordel collected by Sol Biderman. The collection also includes a play, poems, and other writings by Biderman along with his collection of Chicano corridos and poems.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Judy Ng. Assistance with Portuguese language provided by Karina Dos Santos and Ieda Wiarda.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Access to recordings and some fragile materials may be restricted. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
A database containing bibliographic information for the chapbooks in the collection is also available by contacting the Folklife Reading Room.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Sol Biderman collection (AFC 2006/019), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Born in Dallas, Texas in 1936, Sol Biderman has taught literature at universities in California; Genoa and Naples, Italy; and São Paulo, Brazil. He is the author of Bring Me to the Banqueting House and the plays When Elvis Met Che in Denver , To Kill a Mandarin , and Unabomber Hotel .

Biderman's interest in the cordel tradition dates to his tenure at the Faculdade de Filosofia de Marilia in São Paulo, Brazil in the 1960s, when he first began to collect chapbooks and meet the cordelistas who wrote them. In 1970, he donated a substantial portion of his chapbook collection to the Library of Congress (AFC 1970/002), which has continued to acquire literatura de cordel through the Library of Congress Office in Rio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Sol Biderman Collection is comprised of Biderman's writings, research materials, and primary sources for his studies of folk literature including 326 Brazilian chapbooks published between 1958 and 2003, with related materials from other countries, including Mexico and Italy.

The collection includes material on performance, narratives, and Brazilian chapbook illustrating traditions. Three sound recordings, some of which were taped in Pernambuco, Rio Grande do Norte, and Ceara in 1967-1968, capture the recitation of the cordel poems "Beira Mar" and "Galope a Beira Mar." Artifacts and xilogravuras in the collection include a selection of wooden boxes by Guilherme de Faria (a.k.a. Alma Welt); a series of fourteen woodblocks depicting the crucifixion of Christ by João Antonio de Barros; woodblock prints from the Via Sacra series by José Costa Leite; and selected photographs from Inocêncio da Costa Niquel's (Mestre Noza) woodblock Via Sacra series, plus other woodblock prints and posters advertising Biderman's plays. Chapbook authors include: João Martins de Athayde, Abraão Batista, J. (José) Borges, Rodolfo Coelho Cavalcante, Guilherme de Faria, Raimundo Santa Helena, Franklin de C. Machado, José Pacheco, Apolônio Alves dos Santos, and Minelvino Francisco Silva, among others.

Biderman's writings, including a play, poems, and articles form part of the Manuscripts series in the collection. Included are a selection of Chicano corridos and poems written by members of the Teatro Campesino and students of the Universidad Autonomia de Mexico in 1970-1972. Student poems were collected during the time Sol Biderman taught Chicano and English Literature at San Jose State University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged by format into the following series: Series I: Manuscripts; Series II: Sound Recordings; Series III: Graphic Images; Series IV: Artifacts. The chapbooks, graphic images, and artifacts have been arranged by author/creator last name and have been assigned unique numbers. Chapbooks originally housed in wooden boxes crafted by Guilherme de Faria were later added to the end of the chapbook range that was already alphabetized (EP001 to EP283), and can be found in Boxes 6-7 (EP284 to EP326). For an inventory of chapbooks, please see Appendix A. Published materials donated with the collection have been transferred to the Library of Congress General Collections.

Published/bound materials: Dicionário de Flores , Folhas e Frutas and Tradições Paulistas Congadas .

Writings: Catálogo de Literatura de Cordel
Catalog of chapbooks held at the Faculdade de Filosofia, Ciências e Letras de Marília and at the Library of Congress by Sol Biderman, unpublished typescript, 1970.

Writings: O Messias e o Fim do Mundo na Literatura de Cordel

Writings: What Shall I Do In Summer? and other poems
Signed book of poems by Sol Biderman, self published, Rio de Janeiro, 1961.

Writings: Contos da Alma
Songs of Alma by Alma Welt (pseudonym of Guilherme de Faria). One copy each of the unpublished and published manuscript, Editora Palavras e Gestos, São Paulo, 2004.

Series II: Sound Recordings

odd.p: Three sound recordings are original reel-to-reel 3-inch tapes; mono. double track; 7 1⁄2 ips. The tapes of Brazilian Literatura de cordel e cantadores nordestinos were recorded in Pernambuco, Rio Grande do Norte, and Ceara, in 1967-1968. They capture the recitation of the cordel ballad rhythms "Beira Mar" and "Galope a Beira Mar" etc., and other rhythms no longer sung. Sung by Joaquim Batista de Sena, Jose Mota, Manuel Morais, Natal; Jose João dos Santos (who went by the pseudonym of Azulao), Rio; and Francisco Genuíno (Natal).

odd.head: Appendix A: Inventory of Chapbooks
odd.p: Indexed by the last name of the first author of the chapbook. The EP number is the location of the chapbook in the collection containers.
